Award.AwardTitle: Support for Research Team Seminars in Anthropology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project supports three years of research team seminars in cultural anthropology, biological anthropology, and archaeology that will be hosted by the School for Advanced Research (SAR), an advanced research center for anthropology and allied disciplines. The program will support at least two seminars each year for research teams that need focused time together to discuss, synthesize, and analyze the results of their collaborative research and to develop plans for successful completion of their projects. Eligible research teams will be those in which the primary focus is on a question of anthropological importance, but the teams may be interdisciplinary and international in scope. Seminars will be selected through biannual competitions held in March and September. Transportation to and from SAR and all food and lodging will be provided for the research team to meet in SAR's Seminar House for no more than four days.

The project addresses recent studies on the state of U.S. and international scientific inquiry, which identify a trend towards increased collaborative, interdisciplinary, and international research and the increased quality and importance of the products resulting from this research framework. However, studies on the practice of collaborative science also demonstrate that, while digital communication is an important component of team research, face-to-face interaction is also needed to successfully advance the research, which can be a challenge to achieve when the investigators are scattered across the U.S. and in other countries. This program addresses this need and advances collaborative scientific inquiry by providing the opportunity for at least 6 research teams consisting of approximately 10 participants each to assemble at SAR from 2013-2016.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The School for Advanced Research’s (SAR) NSF Research Team Program was initiated as a strategic response to a growing need to support and promote interdisciplinary, collaborative, and international research in anthropology. SAR launched the program in late 2008 with NSF funding (BCS-0824325) and continued with renewed funding in 2013 (BCS-1248491). By the end of the current grant period NSF will have supported nineteen research teams since the program’s inception, including seven during the current grant period (2013-2016). 

Research Team Seminars funded through this program have advanced knowledge by promoting interdisciplinary and international collaboration and disseminating research results via scholarly publications and conference presentations. Though the core discipline of Research Team Seminars is anthropology (archaeological, biological, and cultural), most have been interdisciplinary, with participants from a wide range of allied fields, including history, sociology, museum studies, geography, Latin American studies, public policy, global studies, computer science, economics, engineering, earth and planetary sciences, ecology, evolutionary biology, geosciences, and anatomical sciences.

To date, a number of publications and conference presentations have resulted from seminars that took place during the current grant. Thirteen articles have appeared or are in press in peer reviewed academic journals. Additionally, findings from these seminars have been reported in two books, an edited volume and a monograph, and nine conference presentations. Some co-chairs are publishing academic articles in other languages to reach a broader academic community. For example, the “Land, Water, and Empire in the High-Altitude Atacama” seminar included a number of Spanish speaking scholars from Chile and Spain. Three of the four articles they have published are written in Spanish, and several of the participants presented results in Spanish at an academic conference in Chile.

Research Team Seminars have contributed to building scientific infrastructure by supporting collaboration between academic and industry researchers. Four of the seven NSF Research Team seminars funded during this grant period have represented collaboration between academic and industry researchers. For example, the 2015 seminar on “Innovative Approaches to the Global Water-Energy Nexus” brought together anthropologists and environmental engineers to explore how these scholars and practitioners could collaborate to explore solutions to issues related to global resource management.

Eighty six percent of seminars funded through the current grant included international scholars who travelled from all over the world to meet face-to-face with their team. SAR has hosted research team seminar participants from Albania, Ecuador, the UK, Bangladesh, Croatia, Germany, Canada, Peru, Mexico, and France. For some research teams, the SAR seminar is the only opportunity they have to interact face-to-face.

Many of the Research Team Seminars funded by NSF have also included graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, providing them with valuable, hands-on training in all aspects of the research process, including planning, data collection, analysis, and presentation of findings. As such, the program is helping train future generations of anthropology scholars and practitioners to engage in collaborative, interdisciplinary, international research. Another important broader impact of this program has been research teams sharing results with communities impacted by the research in a format and language that is accessible to them.
